_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

? California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

? Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

? California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

? Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as

necessary. To accomplish this, Wonderful Citrus - Delano (D1) Facility has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist

us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities.



1.1 WONDERFUL CITRUS - DELANO (D1) FACILITY, RISK & PROCESS SAFETY MANAGEMENT PROGRAM



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Wonderful Citrus - Delano (D1) Facility has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been

prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities:



Process Name          Process Chemical           Process Quantity(lbs.)

NER - Cold Storage    Ammonia                     12,000

SER - Degreening      Ammonia                     11,000

NWER - Cold Storage   Ammonia                     15,000



Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of

hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, and illnesses and avoid physical property damage.



Wonderful Citrus - Delano (D1) Facilit

y has an exemplary safety record, one that we are quite proud of. Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker

and public safety. We have:

1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM plan to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well

2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general Wonderful Citrus - Delano (D1) Facility business practices

3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary Wonderful Citrus - Delano (D1) Facility employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures and practices that will help our employees protect themselves and our neighbors.



1.2 PROCESS DESCRIPTIONS



Wonderful Citrus D1 operates a commercial packing and storage facility for oranges in Delano, CA. The facility has three ammonia systems (SER Degreening, NER Cold Storage, and NWER Cold Storage).  



The SER Degreening System provides refrigeration capacity to one (1) plate and frame heat exchanger that is used to chill glycol.  The NER Cold Storage System provides refrigeration capacity to three (3) cold storage rooms and one (1) loading dock.  The NWER System provides refrigeration capacity to one (1) cold storage room and (1) packaging room.  Each system has an Allen Bradley PLC that provides substantial control and alarm capability.



Both the Degreening and NER Cold Storage Systems are pumped overfeed systems and operate as follows:  high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped through a series of liquid feed solenoid valves, an expansion valve, and into a liquid recirculator.  From there, low pressure liquid is pumped to each evaporator, where it passes through a solenoid valve, hand expansion valve and into evaporator.  Low temperature liquid circulates through the evaporator.  Low pressure and temperature gas and overfeed liquid passes through an isolation valve and is returned to the liquid recirculator.  The res

idual liquid is separated from the gas in the recirculator and the suction gas is piped to screw compressors which elevate the temperature and pressure of the gas.  The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to a water cooled evaporative condenser where the high pressure gas ammonia is liquefied and returned to a thermosyphon vessel, and from the thermosyphon vessel it returns to the high pressure receiver. High pressure liquid from the thermosyphon vessel is supplied to the oil coolers on each screw compressor. High temperature liquid is evaporated in the oil cooler and a combination of high temperature gas and liquid is returned to the thermosyphon vessel by thermosyphon action.



The Wonderful Citrus D1 facility was originally built in the 1998 by California Controlled Atmosphere and has been added to since that time.  Most recently the following projects have occurred:



2012/2013 - American Incorporated renovated the computer control system (Cold Storage System and Degreening System)



2012 - American Incorporated installed new evaporative condensers on both systems.



2012 - American Incorporated installed a new high pressure receiver, screw compressor, cold box, and loading dock (Cold Storage System)



2013-2014 - American Incorporated installed the NWER System at Wonderful Citrus D1, which provides refrigeration capacity to Cold Box 4 and a packaging room. 



The NWER System operates as follows: high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped through a liquid feed solenoid valves, an expansion valve, and into the liquid recirculator.  From there, low pressure liquid is pumped to each evaporator, where it passes through a solenoid valve, hand expansion valve and into an air-cooling evaporator. Low temperature liquid circulates through the evaporator.  Low pressure and temperature gas and overfeed liquid passes through an isolation valve and is returned to the liquid recirculator.  The residual liquid is separated from the gas

in the recirculator and the suction gas is piped to the two (2) screw compressors which elevate the temperature and pressure of the gas.  The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to the water cooled evaporative condenser where the high pressure gas ammonia is liquefied and returned to the high pressure receiver.



The NWER System was built in accordance with the 2010 California Mechanical Code. The system contains numerous safety devices including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or pressures exceed or drop below established limits, and safety relief valves which vent ammonia gas to a diffusion tank if the pressure in the system exceeds their set point.



The ammonia systems at Wonderful Citrus D1 consist of vessels which are interconnected, or which are co-located such that a release of ammonia could impact the ability to operate vessels that are not directly connected.  Therefore, each system is treated as a single process.



1.3 GENERAL ACCIDENT RELEASE & CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



1.3.1 GENERAL



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss

preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



Wonderful Citrus - Delano (D1) Facility has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for

the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in the body of the program.



1.3.2 ANHYDROUS AMMONIA



The ammonia refrigeration process at the Wonderful Citrus - Delano (D1) Facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this

process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure t

hat employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.



Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep an active log book of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked

frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment.



1.4 FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



Wonderful Citrus - Delano (D1) Facility has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.



1.5 EMERGENCY ACTION AND RESPONSE PLAN



Wonderful Citrus - Delano (D1) Facility's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

? California "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 8 CCR ?3220

? Federal "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38

? California "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 8 CCR Title 8 ?5192(q)

? Federal "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 29 CFR ?1910.120(q)



Wonderful Citrus has developed a Hazmat Technician Emergency Response Team for responding to releases of anhydrous ammonia. Refer to the facility Emergency Response Plan for more information.



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Our company has an outstanding safety record, one that we are quite proud of. Many policies and procedures have been implemented to promote overall plant, worker and public safety.

Nevertheless, Wonderful Citrus - Delano (D1) Facility continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.



By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Wonderful Citrus - Delano (D1) Facility's ability to

communicate hazardous situations t

o employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Wonderful Citrus - Delano (D1) Facility's management team

can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.



Wonderful Citrus - Delano (D1) Facility has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection,

process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action

item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Wonderful Citrus - Delano (D1) Facility has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain

help with RMP-PSM program implementation. A copy of Resource Compliance's service agreement has been included in this program with the support material.



For the future, Wonderful Citrus - Delano (D1) Facility now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Wonderful Citrus -

Delano (D1) Facility employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Wonderful Citrus - Delano (D1) Facility will continue to maintain overall

plant worker and public safety.
